data.title: Fix OpenGL pixel alignment
data.body:
Fixes #5865. OpenGL packing/unpacking alignment was incorrect. This PR makes MG set the correct alignment when getting/setting data.

Note that alignment needed to be capped at 8 bytes, because OpenGL only allows an alignment of 1, 2, 4 and 8 bytes, but some MG formats have an alignment of 16 bytes.

data.title: Fix casing for readme include in tests
data.body: Casing in the .definition file didn't match file name so the README.md file was not included in the project.

data.title: PVRTexLibNET.PVRTexture.Transcode crashes with SIGFPE on Linux
data.body:
Running the tests on Linux causes a crash with a SIGFPE (arithmetic error, usually caused by division by 0 or overflow) when running [PVRTexLibNET.PVRTexture.Transcode](https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Graphics/PvrtcBitmapContent.cs#L120).

As far as I can tell PVRTexLib is proprietary, so we can't really debug this.

data.title: Missing libpng12 for texture compression on Linux
data.body:
Running tests on Linux I got DLLNotFoundException for nvtt (NVidia Texture Tools) because it depends on libpng 1.2. I had libpng installed, but not 1.2. Installing it on Arch Linux from the official repositories was easy and fixed the issue. We should probably include libpng 1.2 as a dependency.

cc @cra0zy

data.title: TextureFormat Color16Bit does not render odd-width textures correctly (Cross Platform Desktop)
data.body:
Create a Cross Platform Desktop Project.
Create a texture with an odd number pixels width.
Set TextureFormat in Monogame Pipeline Tool to Color16Bit.
Draw the texture in Monogame and it offsets to create a diagonal slanted texture.

The image in the example is 257x256 pixels.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28794554/29240287-f9c41b0a-7f59-11e7-92fe-1a341676d5ab.png)

data.title: Made Game class partial to allow for per-platform extensions
data.body:
This makes the `Game` class a partial class allowing for per-platform extensions.

A good followup would be to pull all the `#if` code out of `Game` and implement them in a platform specific partial class.

For example this feature is used on console platforms where some per-game features are exposed as partial members only when targeting that platform.

data.title: Fix broken XNA tests because of horizontal scroll wheel
Allow switching vsync at runtime in DesktopGL
data.body:
The title says it all. Changing PresentInterval then calling ApplyChanges previously did not work. The value was only checked when a new GraphicsDevice was created.

I added a test to check if graphics state is cleared on reset in XNA. It's not, which matched current MG behavior, so no further changes required there.

data.title: SoundEffect not playing on a WPF and Winforms hosted game
data.body:
Hello. Sounds are not playing when your game is hosted on a WPF/Winforms control (using DirectX of course).
In a normal Monogame window it works perfectly.
Any ideas?

data.title: Added the x86 and x64 binaries to the DesktopGL Installation.
data.body: The x86/x64 Binaries were missing for DesktopGL on Mac (and I assume Linux)

data.title: Fix crash on multi-editing bool values in Pipeline Tool
data.body: Fixes #5858.

data.title: Pipeline crashes when setting a boolean processor parameter for 2+ items with mixed values
data.body:
The MonoGame Pipeline (version 3.6.0.1625) reliably crashes when you select two or more items that have different values for the same processor parameter, then try to set that processor parameter for both simultaneously. It crashes with a NullReferenceException, but I can't get more information than that without digging into MonoGame (which I don't want to do right now).

**Steps to reproduce**
Make a new project.
Add 2 or more images.
Set *Color Key Enabled* to false for one (one is false and one is true).
Select both.
Try to set *Color Key Enabled* by clicking on it. The Pipeline should crash.

**Notes**
This bug exists for any boolean processor parameter.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30244654/28836683-d2f1a650-769e-11e7-9b94-43ff4b510935.png)

data.title: compiled mp3: SharpDXException The system cannot find the file specified
data.body:
With MonoGame version 3.6, I get
`SharpDX.SharpDXException: 'HRESULT: [0x80070002], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: The system cannot find the file specified.`

In VS2017 using the _Monogame Windows Project_ template, with a properly-built Content.mgcb directory of files. The content pipeline has found the .xnb file associated with the song, but is throwing an exception for some other reason. Output contains both .wma and .xnb files for each song as expected.

data.title: UWP Window hangs
MonoGame 3.6 UWP Template is broken for VB.NET
data.body:
So, I recently re-imaged my dev. machine with the latest Windows 10 Creators Update -- so my machine is pretty raw/clean.

I've got Visual Studio 2015, Update 3 -- and I've just pulled down Monogame 3.6 from the official website / installer.

I immediately try to Create a new Monogame project -- and I accidentally selected the VB.NET version without realizing it (instead of C#) -- but I figured, what the heck, let's give this a try.

Upon build, it pulled down a bunch of NuGet packages, and then immediately failed with the following error:

```
Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error		Payload file 'C:\Users\Mikey\.nuget\packages\MonoGame.Framework.WindowsUAP\3.4.0.459\lib\netcore\MonoGame.Framework\MonoGame.Framework.xr.xml' does not exist.	RenderSomething			
```

It seems to me like, maybe the vbproj file is referencing MonoGame 3.4? -- Maybe this might even work if I'd also had MonoGame 3.4 installed. -- But, I bet that might lead to some interesting issues on its own.

data.body: Resolve conflict between #5816 and #5831

data.title: Update console develop branch
data.body: Merge of latest MG develop branch into the console develop branch.  XB1, Switch and PSVita console repos have been updated to work with these changes.

data.title: Improved disposal of OpenGL resources
data.body:
GL resources (textures, buffers, effects, shaders, queries, framebuffers) are now queued by the GraphicsDevice and deleted after the Present on the next frame.  This gives them time to be released by any rendering operations and allows the GC to clean up the wrapper objects.
SDL GL contexts are treated separately since there won't be a GraphicsDevice around to clean them up.

data.title: Improve shader error/warning parsing in Pipeline Tool
data.body:
The new shader compiler produce errors/warnings that include the columnEnd. 
ex.  (26,9-25)

The RegEx was updated to recognize 
single lines, ex: `(26)`
line & column, ex: `(26,9)`
line & column begin & column end, ex: `(26,9-25)`

The RegEx is more strict than before and will fail on invalid strings, ex: `(26,)`  `(,9)`. `(,,,,,)`

Fix: #5846 

![effectwarning](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3018589/28709111-8019d5d4-7387-11e7-841e-dc36796b42e7.png)

data.title: Updated copyright to 2017
MonoGame and UWP
data.body:
Hello,

I have problem by building my UWP app using VS2015 SP3 and MonoGame 3.6.
 The compiler probably produce wrong code, if "Compile with .NET Native tool chain" is active.
 If I disable this feature, then all working fine.

It happened only, if I create a final windows store package.
 The DEBUG and RELEASE builds working fine, if I deploy and start app from debugger.
 But if I create a final windows store package with active "Compile with .NET Native tool chain" and manual install,
 then by start my app showing only SplashScreen and then app be terminated.

If I disable "Compile with .NET Native tool chain" and create a final windows store package,
 then my app working fine by manual install too.

The x86 and x64 packages working fine.
 It's looked that problem only under ARM.

My app using last MonoGame Framework version 3.6 .
 To reproduce problem enough to  create a default (empty) MonoGame Windows 10 Universal Project.
 Then activate "Compile with .NET Native tool chain" and create a final windows store package.
 After build, try to manual install ARM package to any windows phone.
 After start app - it show only SplashScreen and then app be terminated.
 If you disable "Compile with .NET Native tool chain" and create a final windows store package.
 Then by manual install all working fine.

I found similar issues:
https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFramework/issues/6253
https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFramework/issues/6027
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43530071/how-to-fix-app-submission-error-of-1300

but no any solutions not help to resolve this problem.

My question is how I can resolve this problem ?

Did somebody successful generated a submitt any monogame app to MS and successful go thru submission?

thanks,


PS: I just tested with last developer build 3.7.0.678. It's same problem !

I asked help on MS forum: https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/Windowsapps/en-US/0e3dd982-8458-4dce-a513-b51847d8dddf/monogame-and-uwp?forum=wpdevelop
But they not can or not want to help us resolve this problem :-( ...

data.title: PipelineTool - Not showing error line when output filtering on
data.body:
Hi !
I've noticed with the last build (as of 3.7.678) and maybe the previous one or 2, the line and position of the warnings/errors are no more available when using the filtered output.
I have to switch to "text mode" to find the line of the warning/error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19704413/28669220-a4137238-72d3-11e7-94ad-0a29cceaeed2.png)

data.title: Setting hlsl array elements
data.body:
It doesn't work to set individual array elements like this:

`effectParameter.Elements[x].SetValue(value);`

If I understand the code correctly, the ConstantBuffer.Update method checks StateKey to see if a parameter needs updating, and it does so for root parameters only, not caring if an array's elements have been set.

data.title: Simplify FontDescriptionProcessor code
data.body:
Changes that have been made:
 - Adds extra error check at the end in case the font was not found, resolves #5790
 - Platform checking is done withing the code instead of using preprocessing params
 - Added check for extension of "", so that users can put in the actual font file name if they so desire

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Fix project still opening even after an error occured
[Pipeline Tool] Fix double clicking not opening the file
data.body: Double click was opening context menu instead of opening the file.

data.title: [DesktopGL] Fix Joystick enum (fixes #5729)
G-Sync slows down game
data.body:
Just going to jump right into it.

I have my GPU set to "Enable G-SYNC for windowed and full screen mode.".

I just ran my game, and it was noticeably slower, with no change on the frame rate.

Below is a video of both:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ftIuM6Xbhg

Left - this is without G-SYNC
Right - this is with G-SYNC

Now I must say - I'm not trying to make my game "G-SYNC" compatible, but I'm worried that if I were to release the game, those with G-SYNC enabled may have issues, and not know why.

I'm just wondering if this is actually a bug, or am I missing something?
